**Abstract:**

This proposal seeks funding to investigate the impact of funding frictions on financing conditions for countries, banks, pension plans, and life insurance companies in the aftermath of the 2007-2009 global financial crisis (GFC) and the March 2020 Covid-19 market turmoil. Funding frictions, which manifest as elevated external financing costs, shorter debt maturities, and lack of credit market access, have significant implications for the stability of financial institutions and the broader economy. This project aims to advance our understanding of funding frictions, optimize policy responses, and reduce funding risk for institutions. Specifically, we will examine the effects of market developments since the GFC, including ballooning deficits in developed economies, tighter regulation of money market mutual funds, pension risk transfers to life insurance companies, and stricter bank regulation (Basel III). Our research questions will focus on the impact of these changes on funding frictions and credit market access. Expected outcomes include insights on funding costs and credit market access, debt management strategies for sovereigns, and increased policy maker awareness of regulatory consequences. The proposed research will provide valuable guidance for policy makers, financial institutions, and investors seeking to mitigate the negative effects of funding frictions.

Title: Funding Frictions after the Global Financial Crisis

This project investigates the impact of funding frictions on financing conditions for countries, banks, pension plans, and life insurance companies in the post-Global Financial Crisis (GFC) era. Funding frictions, which manifest as elevated external financing costs, shorter debt maturities, and lack of credit market access, have significant implications for the stability of financial institutions and the broader economy. This research aims to understand how market developments since the GFC, including ballooning deficits in developed economies, tighter regulations, and shifts in pension risk transfers, have affected funding frictions and default risk.

The project's key objectives are to optimize policy responses to reduce funding risk for institutions and to inform debt management strategies for sovereigns. By examining the experiences of countries, banks, pension funds, and insurance companies, this research will provide valuable insights into the consequences of funding frictions and inform policy makers on the regulatory consequences of their actions. The project's expected outcomes include a deeper understanding of funding costs and credit market access, as well as practical guidance for policy makers and institutional investors seeking to mitigate the effects of funding frictions. Ultimately, this research will contribute to the development of more effective policy responses to funding frictions, promoting financial stability and reducing the risk of future crises.
